{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3167655,"name":"Alan Tang - Team7587 MutuchenMomentum","username":"alantango","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alantango/{size}/166057_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-19T03:18:39.026Z","cooked":"

We are using CTRE VRM connected to Rev PH. What fuse we should use? 10A or 20A?

The diagram on wpilib wiring doc indicates 10A in one of the 20 high-current channels, see the diagram on below page:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

How to Wire an FRC Robot

Overview: REV CTR Detailed diagram of all of the components and how they are connected. Diagram courtesy of FRC ® Team 3161 and Stefen Acepcion., Detailed diagram of all of the components and how t...

Yet, CTRE VRM user guide calls for connecting it to a 20A protected power supply (.e.g the PDP):

https://store.ctr-electronics.com/content/user-manual/VRM%20User's%20Guide.pdf (page 7)

So which one is it?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-19T03:18:39.026Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":526,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":2662.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":430805,"topic_slug":"fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm","display_username":"Alan Tang - Team7587 MutuchenMomentum","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/latest/docs/zero-to-robot/step-1/how-to-wire-a-robot.html#overview","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"How to Wire an FRC Robot — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":43},{"url":"https://store.ctr-electronics.com/content/user-manual/VRM%20User%27s%20Guide.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":29}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37672,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm/430805/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3167688,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-19T04:41:06.508Z","cooked":"

Can you clarify what youre trying to do? You have a REV Pneumatics Hub powered by a VRM, which is in turn powered by a PDP/PDH? I don’t believe thats a supported configuration, though I don’t know of any specific reason it wouldn’t work, nor can I quote any rules (off the top of my head at least) that explicitly forbid it.

Assuming that is the configuration you have, I’d be inclined to ask “why?” Could you provide any further insoght into the proces?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-19T04:41:06.508Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":122,"readers_count":121,"score":69.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":430805,"topic_slug":"fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm/430805/2","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3167694,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-19T05:27:15.651Z","cooked":"

So there are only 2 variations of the smaller ATC fuses used for the PDP as far as I know. The 10 amp is for the roborio and is yellow or red (will check this tomorrow, but im writing this in bed and don’t have a robot here…) The 20 amp is the other color and is for the VRM and PCM. The PDP has markings on the bottom to indicate which fuse is for which and what components go in which Weidmuller port.

I’m not as familiar with the PDH from rev but I would imagine the answer of 10 for roboRio and 20 for the PCM/VRM port is the same.

As the other people have stated the power goes like so: Battery → breaker → PDP or PDH → VRM/PCM/PCH 20a fuse port of the PDP/PDH

The only devices that are powered from the VRM are usually the radio and small electronics like an Arduino or some led lights. The PCM/PCH is for powering pnuematic solenoids only. All 12v power over 2A that is distributed always comes from the PDP/PDH always always always

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-19T05:34:37.884Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":430805,"topic_slug":"fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm/430805/3","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3167754,"name":"Davo","username":"auscompgeek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/auscompgeek/{size}/9867_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-19T13:12:35.629Z","cooked":"
kingc95:

I’m not as familiar with the PDH from rev but I would imagine the answer of 10 for roboRio and 20 for the PCM/VRM port is the same.

There is no singular fuse for a PCM/PH and VRM on the PDH. They should be connected to separate channels. Only one wire is permitted in each terminal per §9 R618.

R620 stipulates that a single 20A fuse can be used in the PDH low current channels for powering a PCM or PH only. Powering a VRM with a 20A fuse in the low current channels is not allowed under this rule.

I’m not talking about Pneumatic Hub here…we have the typical setup, i.e. Power Distribution Hub from Rev (PDH), not the Power Distribution Panel (PDP) from CTRE, powered by 12v battery. Our VRM is connected to PDH, my inquiry is only on the fuse on the PDH that’s for the VRM. From Mr. Siefen’s input below, it seems we can use 20A fuse. It’s just the wpilib documentation (in my post above) indicated a 10A fuse on PDH in the diagram. Thanks.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-19T13:21:13.668Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":430805,"topic_slug":"fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm","display_username":"Alan Tang - Team7587 MutuchenMomentum","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37672,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm/430805/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3167756,"name":"Davo","username":"auscompgeek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/auscompgeek/{size}/9867_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-19T13:23:34.482Z","cooked":"
alantango:

I’m not talking about Pneumatic Hub here

Your post and title refer to the PH. Seems like that’s where the confusion is coming from.

alantango:

We are using CTRE VRM connected to Rev PH.

alantango:

From Mr. Siefen’s input below, it seems we can use 20A fuse.

Rule R620 does not allow connecting the VRM to a 20A fuse in the PDH. It must be connected to either a fused channel with a fuse of up to 15A, or a high current channel with a breaker of up to 20A per R621 if it isn’t powering a radio.

Furthermore, in the case of a VRM powering a radio, rule R617 says the VRM must be powered from one of the non-switchable fused channels on the PDH with a 10A fuse.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-19T13:29:15.377Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":57,"readers_count":56,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":430805,"topic_slug":"fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm","display_username":"Davo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31229,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4774 mentor, RobotPy dev, CSA/RI"},"post_url":"/t/fuse-for-rev-ph-channel-connecting-to-vrm/430805/6","custom_user_title":"4774 mentor, RobotPy dev, CSA/RI","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3167763,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-19T13:35:17.124Z","cooked":"
auscompgeek:

Your post and title refer to the PH. Seems like that’s where the confusion is coming from.

Yes this was precisely where my comment was coming from.

For everyone’s common understanding (acroynms/initialisms are hard, especially when theres a bunch of similar ones), here’s a non-exhaustive list of ones used by FRC:

  • PDP - Power Distribution Panel by CTRE
  • PDH - Power Distribution Hub by REV
  • VRM - Voltage Regulator Module by CTRE
  • PCM - Pneumatics Control Module by CTRE
  • PH - Pneumatics Hub by REV
  • MPM - Mini Power Module by REV
  • RPM - Radio Power Module by REV
